,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: '''Tanya Atwater''' (Born 1942) is an American [[geophysicist]] and [[Marine geology
Mora: marine geologist]], who specializes in [[plate tectonics]]. She is particularly renowned for her early research on the [[plate tectonic]] history of western North America.

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: Atwater was born in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]] in 1942.<ref name=PSU>{{cite web
column7: accessdate=11 November 2012}}</ref> Her father was an engineer and her mother was a botanist. She is one of four siblings. Atwater was one of the first women to research the [[Seabed
column8: ocean floor]] in terms of its [[Geology]].{{sfn

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: Atwater began her education in 1960 at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]], then received her B.A. in Geophysics from the [[University of California, Berkeley]] in 1965.<ref>{{citation
column5: title=A to Z of earth scientists
column10: pages=10–12}}</ref> She earned a Ph.D. (1972) in [[marine geophysics]] from [[Scripps Institution of Oceanography]], [[University of California, San Diego]]. She is director of the [[University of California, Santa Barbara]] Educational Multimedia Visualization Center where she is an emerita professor of geological sciences. She was a professor at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] before joining the faculty at UCSB in 1980. Atwater retired from UCSB in 2007.<ref>{{cite web

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: Atwater was a professor of [[tectonics]], in the Department of Geological Sciences at the [[University of California, Santa Barbara]] before retiring. She authored and co-authored 50 articles in international journals, professional volumes, and major reports. Seven of these papers were published in the journals ''[[Nature (journal)
Diaz}}: Science]]''. In 1975, she became a fellow of the [[American Geophysical Union]] for her work in [[tectonophysics]].<ref>{{cite web
column7: access-date=2 December 2017}}</ref> From 1975 to 1977, Atwater was a Sloan Postdoctoral Fellowship Recipient in Physics.<ref>{{cite book
column9: title=Postdoctoral Pathways: Preparation, Holding Pattern of Jumping off point?
column13: isbn=978-1421403632}}</ref> In 1984, she won the Encouragement Award from the [[Association for Women Geoscientists]].{{sfn
column15: 2017}} Atwater is a member of the [[National Academy of Sciences]] <ref name='foo'>{{cite web
column19: access-date=1 December 2017}}</ref> for her contributions to marine geophysics and [[tectonics]]. In 2019 she received the highest award of the [[Geological Society of America]], the Penrose Medal.<ref>{{Cite web

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: Atwater was involved in oceanographic expeditions using deep towed instruments to explore the ocean floor. To date, she has participated in 12 deep water dives in the deep-ocean submersible ''[[DSV Alvin
Mora: Alvin]]''.  She researched the volcano-tectonic processes responsible for creating new oceanic crust at [[Mid-ocean ridge
Diaz}}: seafloor spreading centers]].  In 1968, she co-authored a research paper featuring groundbreaking work into the faulted nature of spreading centers.<ref>{{cite journal
column9: title=Changes in direction of sea floor spreading
column15: doi=10.1038/219463a0}}</ref> With [[Jack Corliss]], [[Fred Spiess]], and [[Kenneth C. Macdonald
column16: Kenneth Macdonald]], she played key roles in expeditions that uncovered the distinct biology of ocean floor warm springs, which led to the discovery during the [[RISE project]] of the high temperature black smokers, undersea [[hydrothermal vent]]s.

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: In Atwater's research on [[Propagating Rifts]] near the [[Galápagos Islands
column6: title=Propagating rifts in seafloor spreading patterns
column12: doi=10.1038/290185a0}}</ref> she discovered that propagating rifts were created when spreading centers along the seafloor were disturbed by tectonic movement or [[magma]] and therefore had to change direction to realign. This helped to explain the complex pattern of the seafloor.

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: Atwater is perhaps best known for her work on the [[plate tectonic]] history of western North America.  She wrote two major research papers outlining the history of plate tectonic evolution of North America and tectonic problems of the [[San Andreas Fault]], which assisted in documenting the history of the [[San Andreas Fault Line]].<ref>{{cite journal
column7: title=Relative motion of the Pacific and North American plates deduced from sea-floor spreading in the Atlantic, Indian and South Pacific Oceans
column8: publisher=R. L. Kovach and A. Nur, eds., Proc. of the Conf. on Tectonic Problems of the San Andreas Fault: Stanford University Publication

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: She also studied geometric evolution, integrating and comparing the global plate motion records with the regional continental geologic records.  She found emerging relationships that revealed the origins of many large-scale geologic features (e.g. [[Rocky Mountains]], [[Yellowstone National Park
Atwater research paper, Implications of Plate [[Tectonics]] for the Cenozoic Tectonic Evolution of Western North America,<ref name=\"GeoScienceWorld\">{{cite journal
column5: title=Implications of Plate Tectonics for the Cenozoic Tectonic Evolution of Western North America
column11: doi=10.1130/0016-7606(1970)81[3513:IOPTFT]2.0.CO;2 }}</ref> established the essential framework for the plate tectonics of western North America.  In her work, she explains that approximately 40 million years ago, the [[Farallon Plate]] was subducting underneath the [[North American Plate]] and the [[Pacific Plate]].  The lower half of the Farallon plate was entirely subducted under Southern California and the upper half did not sink, which eventually became known as the [[Juan de Fuca Plate]].Since the southern section of Farallon completely disappeared, the boundary of southern California was now between the Pacific Plate and the North American Plate. The [[San Andreas Fault]] is unique because it acts as a major fault line as well as a border between the [[Pacific Plate]] and the [[North American Plate]].<ref name=\"GeoScienceWorld\"/> She updated this work in 1989.<ref>Atwater, T. M. 1989. “Plate tectonic history of the northeast Pacific and western North America”. In ''The geology of North America: The northeastern Pacific Ocean and Hawaii'', Edited by: Winterer, E. L., Hussong, D. M. and Decker, R. W. Vol. N, 21–72. Boulder, CO: Geol. Soc. Amer.</ref>

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: Atwater is interested in communication and education at all levels. She has developed electronic multi-media (Educational Multimedia Visualization Center at UCSB) to enhance geologic visualization and understanding, particularly related to the histories of tectonic plates.<ref>{{cite web
* 1980, AAAS Newcomb Cleveland Prize for top research article in the journal [http://www.sciencemag.org Science]<ref name=\"Atwater\">{{cite web
column4: title=Faculty Accolades Earth Sciences, UC Santa Barbara

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: * 1997, elected to the [[United States National Academy of Sciences
Diaz}}: title=National Academy of Sciences, Member Directory

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: * 2002, [[National Science Foundation]] Director's Award for Distinguished Teaching Scholars. This award, of $300,000 over four years, is given to help and honor distinguished scientists who are working out ways to translate research into education. The money is meant to provide teaching scholars the opportunity to expand their work beyond their home institutions.<ref>{{cite web
Mora: title=Calling all geologists: Put your mental pictures here

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: * Leopold von Buch Medal, German Geosciences Society<ref name=\"Atwater\"/>
*2005 Gold Medal, [[Society of Woman Geographers]]<ref name=\"Medal\">{{cite web

Mora: Penrose Medal]] of the Geological Society of America.<ref>{{Cite web

* Atwater, Tanya, 1970, Implications of plate tectonics for the Cenozoic tectonic evolution of western North America. Bull. Geol. Soc. Amer., v. 81, p. 3513-3536. * Atwater, Tanya, and P. Molnar, 1973, Relative motion of the Pacific and North American plates deduced from seafloor spreading in the Atlantic, Indian and South Pacific Oceans. R. L. Kovach and A. Oceanography., Contributions, Vol. 44, Part 2, p. 1362–1374, 1974.
* Atwater, Tanya, 1981, Propagating rifts in seafloor spreading patterns. Nature, v. 290, p. 185 186.
* Atwater, T., 1991, Tectonics of the Northeast Pacific, Transactions of the Royal Society of Canada, Series I, v. I, pp. 295–318.

* Atwater, T., 1998, Plate Tectonic History of Southern California with emphasis on the Western Transverse Ranges and Santa Rosa Island, in Weigand, P. '''Militia organizations in the United States''' are private organizations that include [[paramilitary]] or similar elements. These groups may refer to themselves as '''[[Militia (United States)
Mora: militia]]''', '''unorganized militia''',<ref>Mulloy, Darren (2004) ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=aaBKyuLRjR0C American Extremism: History, Politics and the Militia Movement]'', Routledge.</ref> and '''[[Constitutional militia movement
Diaz}}: constitutional militia]]'''.<ref>Williams, David C. (2003) [https://books.google.com/books?id=9IReoC_EcJ4C&pg=PA363 ''The mythic meanings of the Second Amendment: taming political violence in a constitutional republic'']. Yale University Press. p. 363. {{ISBN

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: While groups such as the [[Posse Comitatus (organization)
Mora: Posse Comitatus]] existed as early as the 1980s,<ref name=\"CAMO\">Pitcavage, Mark; Institute for Intergovernmental Research: ''Camouflage and Conspiracy. The Militia Movement From Ruby Ridge to Y2K''. American Behavioral Scientist, Vol. 44, No. 6, Pages 957–981, SAGE Publications, 2001.</ref> the movement gained momentum after controversial standoffs with government agents in the early 1990s. By the mid-1990s, groups were active in all 50 US states, with membership estimated at between 20,000 and 60,000.<ref name=\"RIGHT\">Berlet, Chip & Lyons, Matthew (2000). ''[http://www.researchforprogress.us/rwpop/nwo.html Right-Wing Populism in America: Too Close for Comfort]'', Guilford. {{ISBN
column4: title = F.E.A.R. Militia Wanted To Bomb Georgia Park

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: Militia have been a nessesary private organization since the formation of the United States.
During the 1990s public attention to the militia movement began to grow.{{citation needed
Mora: date=April 2014}} The [[Oklahoma City bombing]] on April 19, 1995, the second anniversary of the Waco fire, drew nationwide attention to the militia movement as [[Timothy McVeigh]] was erroneously associated with the [[Michigan Militia]].{{citation needed
Diaz}}: date=April 2014}} This increased public scrutiny and law enforcement pressure, and brought in more recruits due to the heightened awareness of the movement.<ref name=\"MILITIA\">[http://www.publiceye.org/rightist/milnatbl.html Militia Nation] Chip Berlet and Matthew N. Lyons ''Progressive Magazine''</ref>

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: In March 1996, agents of the FBI and other law enforcement organizations surrounded the {{convert
column5: sing=on}} eastern [[Montana]] \"Justus Township\" compound of the [[Montana Freemen]]. The Freemen were a [[Sovereign Citizen Movement
column6: Sovereign Citizen]] group that included elements of the [[Christian Identity]] ideology, espoused [[common law]] legal theories, and rejected the legitimacy of the [[Federal Reserve]].<ref name=\"RIGHT\"/> Montana legislator Carl Ohs mediated through the standoff. Both [[Randy Weaver]] (one of the besieged at [[Ruby Ridge]]) and [[Bo Gritz]] (a civilian negotiator at Ruby Ridge) had attempted to talk to the group but had given up in frustration, as did Colorado Senator [[Charlie Duke]] when he had attempted negotiations.<ref name=\"SURRENDER\">[http://www.cnn.com/US/9606/13/freemen.11p/ Freemen surrender peacefully to FBI] ''Cable News Network'' June 14, 1996</ref> A break finally came when far right leaders abandoned the group to their fate.<ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9902E5D61739F936A25755C0A960958260 Freemen Were Alone] ''New York Times'' June 15, 1996</ref> The group surrendered peacefully after an 81-day standoff and 14 of the Freemen faced criminal charges relating to circulating millions of dollars in bogus checks and threatening the life of a federal judge.<ref name=\"SURRENDER\"/> The peaceful resolution of this and other standoffs after Ruby Ridge and Waco have been credited by some to the creation of the Critical Incident Response Group ([[CIRG]]) in the U.S. Department of Justice in 1994.<ref>Christopher Whitcomb, ''Cold Zero: Inside the FBI Hostage Rescue Team''. {{ISBN

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: A 1999 US Department of Justice analysis of the potential militia threat at the Millennium conceded that the vast majority of militias were reactive (not proactive) and posed no threat.<ref>United States Department of Justice, \"Operation Megiddo\", November 2, 1999, page 22; cited in Robert H. Churchill, \"Arming for the Last Battle: Secular and Religious Millennial Impulses within the Militia Movement\", 1999 Annual Conference of the Center for Millennial Studies, Boston University, Boston, MA, November 9, 1999.</ref> By 2001, the militia movement seemed to be in decline, having peaked in 1996 with 858 groups.<ref>{{cite news
column6: post-2007 global financial crisis]] and the election of [[Barack Obama]] to the United States presidency in 2008, militia activity has experienced a resurgence.<ref name=carter2012>{{cite book
column8: title=Guns in American Society: An Encyclopedia of History, Politics, Culture, and the Law, Volume 1
column13: title=Election, economy spark explosive growth of militias
column18: title=America's militiamen resurgent since Obama election
column20: publisher=The National}}</ref> Militia groups have recently been involved in several high-profile standoffs, including [[Bundy standoff
column21: the Bundy Standoff]] in 2014 and the [[Occupation of the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge]] in 2016 amid a renewed rise in anti-government militia movements.

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: The United States Constitution provides for and defines the formation, training and use of these Mitlitia in every city, county and state to provide defense against governmmet tyrany or overreach.  They are authorized by the United States constitution and are a vital part of citizens maintaing strict control over public servants. (Senators, House members, all employees of state and local services are considered public servants) Without the formation of militia enough force could not be mustered to defeat a tyranical government.

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: [[Category:Paramilitary organizations based in the United States]]
[[Category:Right-wing militia organizations in the United States
'''Militia organizations in the United States''' are private organizations that include [[paramilitary]] or similar elements. These groups may refer to themselves as '''[[Militia (United States)
Mora: militia]]''', '''unorganized militia''',<ref>Mulloy, Darren (2004) ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=aaBKyuLRjR0C American Extremism: History, Politics and the Militia Movement]'', Routledge.</ref> and '''[[Constitutional militia movement
Diaz}}: constitutional militia]]'''.<ref>Williams, David C. (2003) [https://books.google.com/books?id=9IReoC_EcJ4C&pg=PA363 ''The mythic meanings of the Second Amendment: taming political violence in a constitutional republic'']. Yale University Press. p. 363. {{ISBN

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: While groups such as the [[Posse Comitatus (organization)
Mora: Posse Comitatus]] existed as early as the 1980s,<ref name=\"CAMO\"/> the movement gained momentum after controversial standoffs with government agents in the early 1990s. By the mid-1990s, groups were active in all 50 US states, with membership estimated at between 20,000 and 60,000.<ref name=\"RIGHT\">Berlet, Chip & Lyons, Matthew (2000). ''[http://www.researchforprogress.us/rwpop/nwo.html Right-Wing Populism in America: Too Close for Comfort]'', Guilford. {{ISBN
column4: title = F.E.A.R. Militia Wanted To Bomb Georgia Park

Mora: far-right]] [[patriot movement]] had long been a fringe factor in American politics,{{citation needed
Diaz}}: date=January 2016}} cultural factors paved the way for the wide-scale growth of the ideological militia movement.  The catalysts came in the form of the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation
column4: FBI]]'s 1992 shootout with [[Randy Weaver]] at [[Ruby Ridge]], and the government's 1993 [[Waco siege
column5: siege]] and eventual destruction of [[David Koresh]]'s compound and the [[Branch Davidians]] at Mt. Carmel in [[Waco, Texas]].<ref name=\"ANGRY\">[http://www.publiceye.org/rightist/dj_mili.html Rise Of Citizen Militias: Angry White Guys With Guns] Daniel Junas ''CovertAction Quarterly'' April 24, 1995</ref><ref>[[Morris Dees]], ''Gathering Storm: America's Militia Threat''. Harper Perennial (April 23, 1997) {{ISBN
column6: 0-06-092789-5}}</ref><ref name=\"ARMING\">Robert H. Churchill, \"Arming for the Last Battle: Secular and Religious Millennial Impulses within the Militia Movement\", 1999 Annual Conference of the Center for Millennial Studies, Boston University, Boston, MA, November 9, 1999. [http://uhaweb.hartford.edu/CHURCHILL/CMS_Paper.pdf Online copy]</ref> Critic [[Mark Pitcavage]] described the militia movement of the 1990s:<ref name=\"CAMO\">Pitcavage, Mark; Institute for Intergovernmental Research: ''Camouflage and Conspiracy. The Militia Movement From Ruby Ridge to Y2K''. American Behavioral Scientist, Vol. 44, No. 6, Pages 957–981, SAGE Publications, 2001.</ref>

Mora: The militia movement is a right-wing movement that arose following controversial standoffs in the 1990s. It inherited paramilitary traditions of earlier groups, especially the conspiratorial, anti-government [[Posse Comitatus (organization)
Diaz}}: Posse Comitatus]]. The militia movement claims that militia groups are sanctioned by law but uncontrolled by government; in fact, they are designed to oppose a tyrannical government. The movement's ideology has led some adherents to commit criminal acts, including stockpiling illegal weapons and explosives and plotting to destroy buildings or assassinate public officials, as well as lesser confrontations.}}

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: During the 1990s public attention to the militia movement began to grow.{{citation needed
Mora: date=April 2014}} The [[Oklahoma City bombing]] on April 19, 1995, the second anniversary of the Waco fire, drew nationwide attention to the militia movement as [[Timothy McVeigh]] was erroneously associated with the [[Michigan Militia]].{{citation needed
Diaz}}: date=April 2014}} This increased public scrutiny and law enforcement pressure, and brought in more recruits due to the heightened awareness of the movement.<ref name=\"MILITIA\">[http://www.publiceye.org/rightist/milnatbl.html Militia Nation] Chip Berlet and Matthew N. Lyons ''Progressive Magazine''</ref>

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: In March 1996, agents of the FBI and other law enforcement organizations surrounded the {{convert
column5: sing=on}} eastern [[Montana]] \"Justus Township\" compound of the [[Montana Freemen]]. The Freemen were a [[Sovereign Citizen Movement
column6: Sovereign Citizen]] group that included elements of the [[Christian Identity]] ideology, espoused [[common law]] legal theories, and rejected the legitimacy of the [[Federal Reserve]].<ref name=\"RIGHT\"/> Montana legislator Carl Ohs mediated through the standoff. Both [[Randy Weaver]] (one of the besieged at [[Ruby Ridge]]) and [[Bo Gritz]] (a civilian negotiator at Ruby Ridge) had attempted to talk to the group but had given up in frustration, as did Colorado Senator [[Charlie Duke]] when he had attempted negotiations.<ref name=\"SURRENDER\">[http://www.cnn.com/US/9606/13/freemen.11p/ Freemen surrender peacefully to FBI] ''Cable News Network'' June 14, 1996</ref> A break finally came when far right leaders abandoned the group to their fate.<ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9902E5D61739F936A25755C0A960958260 Freemen Were Alone] ''New York Times'' June 15, 1996</ref> The group surrendered peacefully after an 81-day standoff and 14 of the Freemen faced criminal charges relating to circulating millions of dollars in bogus checks and threatening the life of a federal judge.<ref name=\"SURRENDER\"/> The peaceful resolution of this and other standoffs after Ruby Ridge and Waco have been credited by some to the creation of the Critical Incident Response Group ([[CIRG]]) in the U.S. Department of Justice in 1994.<ref>Christopher Whitcomb, ''Cold Zero: Inside the FBI Hostage Rescue Team''. {{ISBN

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: A 1999 US Department of Justice analysis of the potential militia threat at the Millennium conceded that the vast majority of militias were reactive (not proactive) and posed no threat.<ref>United States Department of Justice, \"Operation Megiddo\", November 2, 1999, page 22; cited in Robert H. Churchill, \"Arming for the Last Battle: Secular and Religious Millennial Impulses within the Militia Movement\", 1999 Annual Conference of the Center for Millennial Studies, Boston University, Boston, MA, November 9, 1999.</ref> By 2001, the militia movement seemed to be in decline, having peaked in 1996 with 858 groups.<ref>{{cite news
column6: post-2007 global financial crisis]] and the election of [[Barack Obama]] to the United States presidency in 2008, militia activity has experienced a resurgence.<ref name=carter2012>{{cite book
column8: title=Guns in American Society: An Encyclopedia of History, Politics, Culture, and the Law, Volume 1
column13: title=Election, economy spark explosive growth of militias
column18: title=America's militiamen resurgent since Obama election
column20: publisher=The National}}</ref> Militia groups have recently been involved in several high-profile standoffs, including [[Bundy standoff
column21: the Bundy Standoff]] in 2014 and the [[Occupation of the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge]] in 2016 amid a renewed rise in anti-government militia movements.

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: Most militia organizations envisage themselves as legally legitimate organizations authorized under constitutional and statute law, specifically references in state and federal law to an \"unorganized militia\".{{fact
Mora: date=January 2020}} Others subscribe to the \"insurrection theory\" which describes the right of the [[body politic]] to rebel against the established government in the face of tyranny. (In the 1951 case ''[[Dennis v. United States]]'', the U.S. Supreme Court rejected the insurrection theory, stating that as long as the government provides for free elections and trials by jury, \"political self-defense\" cannot be undertaken.)<ref>{{cite journal
column5: title=The Inconvenient Militia Clause of the Second Amendment: Why the Supreme Court Declines to Resolve the Debate over the Right to Bear Arms
column6: journal=St. John's Journal of Legal Commentary

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: While militia organizations have a variety of ideologies and objectives, with many high profile organizations espousing [[Tax protester
column8: date=December 2018}} they generally share a common belief in the imminent or actual rise of a tyrannical government in the [[United States]] which, they believe, must be confronted through armed force.<ref>{{cite news
column20: accessdate=4 January 2016}}</ref> Some believe in the [[New World Order (conspiracy theory)
column21: New World Order conspiracy theory]].<ref>[https://think.kera.org/2016/08/30/the-hate-map-of-america/ The Hate Map Of America] - Interview with Mark Potok, investigative reporter for the Southern Poverty Law Center</ref>

Mora: List of militia organizations in the United States}}

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: '''North Conway''' is a [[census-designated place]] (CDP) and [[Village (New Hampshire)
Mora: village]] in eastern [[Carroll County, New Hampshire
Diaz}}: Carroll County]], [[New Hampshire]], United States. The population was 2,349 at the [[2010 United States Census
column6: title=Geographic Identifiers: 2010 Demographic Profile Data (G001): North Conway CDP, New Hampshire
column11: url-status=dead}}</ref> A year-round resort area, North Conway is the largest village within the town of [[Conway, New Hampshire
column12: Conway]], which is bounded on the east by the [[Maine]] state line. The [[White Mountain National Forest]] is to the west and north. Conway is home to Cathedral Ledge (popular with [[climbing
column13: climbers]]), [[Echo Lake State Park]], and [[Cranmore Mountain Resort
column14: Mount Cranmore]]. North Conway is known for its large number of [[outlet mall

Diaz}}: Aerial view of North Conway and [[Cranmore Mountain Resort

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: Chartered in 1765 by Colonial Governor [[Benning Wentworth]], the town is named for [[Henry Seymour Conway]], ambitious son of a prominent [[English people
Mora: English]] family, who was elected to the [[British House of Commons
Diaz}}: House of Commons]] at age 20, fought at [[Battle of Culloden
column4: Culloden]], and became [[Secretary of state (United Kingdom)
column5: Secretary of State]]. Early settlers called the area [[Pequawket]] (known colloquially as Pigwacket), adopting the name of the [[Abenaki]] [[Native Americans in the United States
column6: Indian]] village which stretched down the [[Saco River]] to its [[stockade]]d center at [[Fryeburg, Maine]].

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: North Conway is in the [[White Mountains (New Hampshire)
Diaz}}: Mount Washington]] to the northwest. The rugged terrain became popular in the 19th century with artists. Their paintings were known collectively as [[White Mountain art]], which in turn attracted tourists to the area, particularly after the [[Portsmouth, Great Falls & Conway Railroad]] extended service in 1872 to North Conway. In 1874, the line [[North Conway Depot and Railroad Yard
column6: depot]], designed by [[Nathaniel J. Bradlee]]. In 1932, \"snow trains\" began carrying enthusiasts to \"the birthplace of American [[alpine skiing
column7: skiing]],\" as North Conway is known.{{Citation needed

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: Increasing automobile travel brought the decline of trains. The railroad, then part of the [[Boston and Maine Railroad
Mora: Boston & Maine]], abandoned passenger service to the area in 1961 and [[freight]] service in 1972. Subsequently, the [[Conway Scenic Railroad]] was established. Today, the line offers visitors a tour of the region, including [[Crawford Notch]]. The station is listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]].

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: In the late 1980s, the [[White Mountain Airport (New Hampshire)
Mora: White Mountain Airport]] closed and was redeveloped as a large outlet mall called [[Settlers' Green Outlet Village]]. Continued growth through the 1990s and 2000s in North Conway and the villages nearby made Conway the most populous community in [[Carroll County, New Hampshire
Diaz}}: Carroll County]]. Traffic congestion led to an overhaul of the road system, including widening [[New Hampshire Route 16
column4: Route 16]] through North Conway village and constructing a road parallel to Route 16 to allow traffic to move between [[Redstone, New Hampshire
column7: bypass]] of the area is being developed.

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: North Conway remains a popular destination due to its shopping, recreation, and attractions.

North Conway and its surrounding towns offer [[hiking]] in the [[White Mountain National Forest]]. The area is a major [[rock climbing]] destination in the [[northeastern United States]],<ref>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=June 22, 2010}}</ref> particularly Cathedral Ledge in Echo Lake State Park. The {{convert
column10: Echo Lake]] and North Conway from the west. Unlike nearby White Horse Ledge, another rock climbing site, Cathedral Ledge has an automobile road to the summit, which provides fine views of the Saco River Valley.

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: In late September through early October, tourists arrive to see the [[autumn foliage]] on the surrounding mountains and forests. The [[Conway Scenic Railroad]] features train rides that leave from the village's [[Victorian architecture
Mora: Victorian]] station. In the winter, the village is the nighttime destination for [[skiing
Diaz}}: skiers]] visiting the area resorts, including North Conway's own [[Cranmore Mountain Resort
column4: Cranmore Mountain]] as well as nearby [[Attitash]] Resort, [[Black Mountain Ski Area (New Hampshire)
column5: Black Mountain]] and [[Wildcat Mountain Ski Area

column15: title=US Gazetteer files: 2010, 2000, and 1990}}</ref> in the northern part of the town of [[Conway, New Hampshire

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the village, a census-designated place (CDP), has a total area of {{convert
column10: disp=flip}}, or 1.29%, is water.<ref name=\"Census 2010\"/> North Conway is drained by the [[Saco River]].

column4: White Horse Ledge and Echo Lake c. 1908]]

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: As of the [[census]] of 2010, there were 2,349 people, 1,105 households, and 547 families residing in the CDP. The [[population density]] was 546.3 people per square mile (211.9/km²). There were 1,804 housing units, of which 699, or 38.7%, were vacant. 551 of the vacant units were seasonal or vacation properties. The racial makeup of the CDP was 94.7% [[White (U.S. Census)
column5: Asian]], 0.1% Native Hawaiian or other Pacific Islander, 0.6% [[Race (United States Census)
column6: some other race]], and 1.7% from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)
column8: Latino]] of any race were 1.6% of the population.<ref name=\"Census 2010 DP\">{{cite web
column10: title=Profile of General Population and Housing Characteristics: 2010 Demographic Profile Data (DP-1): North Conway CDP, New Hampshire

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: There were 1,105 households, out of which 23.3% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 33.1% were headed by [[Marriage
Mora: married couples]] living together, 11.4% had a female householder with no husband present, and 50.5% were non-families. 39.9% of all households were made up of individuals, and 12.8% were someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.07, and the average family size was 2.73.<ref name=\"Census 2010 DP\"/>

column4: The [[Kearsarge House]] c. 1910, an early grand hotel]]

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: In the CDP, the population was spread out with 18.6% under the age of 18, 8.4% from 18 to 24, 26.8% from 25 to 44, 29.1% from 45 to 64, and 16.8% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 42.1 years. For every 100 females, there were 99.9 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 92.5 males.<ref name=\"Census 2010 DP\"/>

For the period 2007-11, the estimated median annual income for a household in the CDP was $40,804, and the median income for a family was $46,832. Male full-time workers had a median income of $31,764 versus $23,859 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the CDP was $21,664. About 12.1% of families and 21.9% of the population were below the [[poverty line]].<ref>{{cite web
Diaz}}: title=Selected Economic Characteristics: 2007-2011 American Community Survey 5-Year Estimates (DP03): North Conway CDP, New Hampshire

* [[E. E. Cummings]], 20th century poet; summer resident; died (of a stroke) in North Conway, on September 3, 1962

The median age was 42.1 years. For every 100 females, there were 99.9 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 92.5 males.<ref name=\"Census 2010 DP\"/>

For the period 2007-11, the estimated median annual income for a household in the CDP was $40,804, and the median income for a family was $46,832. Male full-time workers had a median income of $31,764 versus $23,859 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the CDP was $21,664. About 12.1% of families and 21.9% of the population were below the [[poverty line]].<ref>{{cite web
Diaz}}: title=Selected Economic Characteristics: 2007-2011 American Community Survey 5-Year Estimates (DP03): North Conway CDP, New Hampshire

Mora: name               = <!-- include middle initial, if not specified in birth_name -->
image              = Bob Hallett.jpg<!-- filename only, no \"File:\" or \"Image:\" prefix, and no enclosing [[brackets]] -->
alt                = <!-- descriptive text for use by speech synthesis (text-to-speech) software -->
birth_name         = Robert (Bob) Hallett<!-- only use if different from name -->
occupation         = Musician, Talent manager, Record producer, Author
known_for          = [[Great Big Sea]] (band member), [[Come From Away]] (music consultant)

Canadian]] [[musician]], author, producer, and entrepreneur, best known as a founding member of the Canadian [[folk rock]] band [[Great Big Sea]] (1993–2013). He is also a native of [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador
Diaz}}: St. John's, Newfoundland]], Hallett co-founded Great Big Sea in 1993, with [[Alan Doyle]], [[Sean McCann (musician)
column4: Sean McCann]]<nowiki/>, and [[Darrell Power]]. The band sold over a million and half records around the world, over a twenty-year period. Through his company, Kilbride Music, Hallett has [[Talent manager
column6: produced]] records, radio specials, and live concerts.<ref>{{cite news
column10: title=East Coast Music Association (ECMA) still a music industry 'catalyst' after 30 years
column14: access-date= 7 Jan 2018}}</ref> Hallet is a vocal proponent of talent development within the Newfoundland and East Coast Music Industries, and has authored a career guidebook for aspiring musicians.<ref>{{cite news
column18: title=Aspiring musicians need to 'work hard,' says Bob Hallett
column26: title= The Art of Managing your career in Music and Sound Recording
column29: publisher=[[HRDC]] - Cultural Human Resources Council of Canada
column32: author-link= }}</ref> He works with the producers of the Broadway musical ''[[Come From Away]]'' as a Music Consultant, and has also worked at the [[Stratford Festival]] as a Composer & Music Director. As an author he has written dozens of magazine articles, essays and several books, including the best-selling memoir ''Writing Out The Notes''. He is the owner of Erin's Pub and Tavola Restaurant in downtown St. John's.{{citation needed
column33: date=January 2018}} Hallett currently plays accordion and other instruments in the band Kelly Russell and the Planks; he has also been associated with [[The Once]], The Dardanelles, Fabian James, and the Irish Descendants, in various capacities.{{citation needed

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: Hallett attended [[Memorial University of Newfoundland]], where he completed a Bachelor of Arts in English and History in 1989. The other members of ''Great Big Sea'' attended Memorial University at the same time, and together were named Alumni of the Year in 1999. Prior to becoming a full-time musician, Hallett served as Managing Editor of the Newfoundland Herald and as a Communications Officer with Employment and Immigration Canada.
A founding member of [[Great Big Sea]], Hallett performed vocals, mandolin, mandola, bouzouki, banjo, fiddle, whistles, bagpipes, accordion, and concertina with the band.<ref name=\"ency\">{{cite web
column9: Séan McCann]] began playing together in a Celtic band called ''Rankin Street'' in 1989, with [[Alan Doyle]] joining in 1993.<ref name=\"ency\"/> Rankin Street built a following playing at local St. John's pubs, including Bridget's and Greensleeves, and released one recording on [[Compact cassette
column10: cassette]] titled \"Rankin Street\". As Great Big Sea, the group played its first official gig on March 11, 1993, opening for the [[Irish Descendants]] at [[Memorial University of Newfoundland
column11: Memorial University]], and focusing on playing traditional instruments.{{citation needed
column12: date=January 2018}} Great Big Sea released nine albums between 1993 and 2010, including several platinum and gold titles. Touring intensively, the band and band members gained acclaim across North America prior to retiring in 2013 following a 20th anniversary tour. Highlights include reaching the top ten of the Canadian [[RPM (magazine)
column13: RPM]] pop chart in 1997 with [[The Rough Guide to World Music
column14: \"When I'm Up (I Can't Get Down)]]\", a cover of a song by the British folk group [[Oysterband]];<ref>{{Cite web
column21: title=50 legendary Canadian songs in honour of Canada's 150th birthday
column24: language=en}}</ref> winning the Entertainer of the Year award at the East Coast Music Awards every year between 1996 and 2000;[5] and receiving nominations for several [[Juno Award]]s<ref>{{cite web
column25: title= Juno Awards/Canadian Music Hall of Fame winner and nominations
column28: access-date=26 Nov 2006}}</ref> including Group of the Year in 1998, 2005, 2009, and 2011.

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: Since 2015, Hallett has served as the Newfoundland Music Consultant for the [[Tony Award]]-winning Broadway theater production ''[[Come from Away]]''.<ref>

column5: title=Come From Away goes home to Gander, Nfld. before heading to Broadway

Diaz}}: title=Bob Hallett: what dreams are made of
book]], music, and lyrics by Irene Sankoff and [[David Hein]]; the ''[[Rock music]]-feel'' of the musical has been attributed to Hallett's contributions.<ref>{{cite news
column7: title=Come From Away – World Premiere at La Jolla Playhouse
column11: access-date=9 Jan 2018 }}</ref> Set in the week following the [[September 11 attacks]], the musical tells the true story of what transpired when 38 planes were ordered to land unexpectedly in the small town of [[Gander, Newfoundland and Labrador]], as part of [[Operation Yellow Ribbon]]. At the [[71st Tony Awards]], the production was nominated for seven awards including [[Tony Award for Best Musical
column12: Best Musical]], [[Tony Award for Best Original Score
column13: Best Score]], [[Tony Award for Best Book of a Musical
column14: Best Book of a Musical]]<nowiki/>and [[Tony Award for Best Featured Actress in a Musical
column15: Best Featured Actress in a Musical]] for [[Jenn Colella]], ultimately winning for [[Tony Award for Best Direction of a Musical
column16: Best Direction of a Musical]]. In November 2017, plans for a [[Mark Gordon Company]] feature film adaptation were announced.<ref>{{cite news
column20: title=Tony-Winning 'Come From Away' Director Boards Feature Film Adaptation For Mark Gordon Co.

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: In 2015, Hallett served as Musical [[Composer]] and [[Arrangement
Mora: Arranger]] for the [[Stratford Festival]] production of Shakespeare's ''[[As You Like It]],'' directed by [[Jillian Keiley]].<ref>{{cite web
column4: title= Great Big Sea's Bob Hallett finds new voice as theatrical composer
column11: quote=}}</ref> In this adaptation, the play was set in Newfoundland in the 1980s, and audience members were encouraged to participate in the performance, incorporating props that the audience selected when entering the lobby. All music was composed by Hallett and played by a roots band.<ref>{{Cite news
column13: title=Newfoundland setting draws audience into Stratford's As You Like It

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: Hallett is the author of four books.
*''Writing Out the Notes'', Hallett's reflections on life in the band [[Great Big Sea]] and the [[Music of Canada
*''The Ten - Most Decisive Battles on American Soil'' (juvenile [[nonfiction]])

*''The Art of Managing Your Career in Music and Sound Recording''. A guide for musicians and recording artists, this book is part of the online learning curriculum offered by the Cultural Human Resources Council of Canada ([[HRDC]])
Nominated for the [[East Coast Music Association]] ''Manager of the Year'' award in 2015, 2016, and 2017, '''Kilbride Music''' is a [[Talent manager
Diaz}}: production]] firm operated by Hallett and business partner Michelle Robertson.<ref>

column4: title=ECMA 2015 nominations for 35 N.L. musicians, industry people
column10: title= Local artists leading the ECMA pack
column17: title= East Coast Music Awards announces 2017 nominations

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: With Chris Andrews (of the band Shanneyganock), Hallett co-owns ''Erin's Pub'', a traditional Newfoundland bar known as a ''kitchen party'' place. The establishment was the first [[Irish pub]] in Newfoundland, has played a role in launching bands, and was featured in a 2014 [[Cody Westman]] documentary (''That LITTLE Room - The Story Of Erin's Pub'') that aired on all [[Air Canada]] flights in 2014.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=Erin's Pub chronicled in new documentary

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: Great Big Sea won the ''Entertainer of the Year'' award at the [[East Coast Music Awards]] for every year between 1996 and 2000. In 2001, they decided not to submit their name for nomination in order to allow other bands to compete. They were nominated for several [[Juno Award]]s, including Group of the Year.
Hallett has served as a Co-Chair and Board Member to the East Coast Music Association and Awards.<ref>{{cite web
In late 2005, Great Big Sea released its first [[podcast]], with clips of the band bantering back and forth in the studio mixed with various songs by them and other artists.{{citation needed
Mora: date=January 2018}} The Great Big Sea Song \"Oh Yeah\", written and performed by Doyle, McCann, Hallett, Hawsley Workman, and Jeen O'Brien, was featured in the opening credits of the [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] show ''[[Republic of Doyle]]''. Set and filmed in St. John's, Newfoundland, Republic of Doyle launched in 2010 as a new drama, with one of the largest budgets in CBC history.<ref>{{cite news
column6: title=Doyle visits the Republic of Doyle

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: In 2016, Hallett successfully campaigned to halt [[Walmart]] sales of [[Saint Patrick's Day]] T-shirts that featured a [[racial slur]] considered offensive to native [[Newfoundland and Labrador
column13: title=Has a Canadian Slur Lost Its Sting?

[[Category:Writers from St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador]]","{{notability<!--All claims appear to be inherited notability-->

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: '''''Jealous Ones Still Envy 2 (J.O.S.E. 2)''''' is the ninth solo [[studio album]] by American rapper [[Fat Joe]], and is a sequel to his platinum-selling album ''[[Jealous Ones Still Envy (J.O.S.E.)
Mora: Jealous Ones Still Envy]]'' (2001).<ref name=\"DX\">{{cite magazine
column5: title=Fat Joe Set to Release J.O.S.E. 2
column14: title=Fat Joe Readies New Album: Jealous Ones Still Envy 2 Out April 7
column17: date=February 26, 2009}}</ref> It is also the third album in his [[Jealous One's Envy]] series. After several delays, the album was released on October 6, 2009. The album's production was done by [[Rico Love]], [[Ron Browz]], [[Lee Major
column18: The Inkredibles]], [[Eric Hudson]], [[Jim Jonsin]] and [[DJ Infamous]], and features guest contributions from rappers [[Lil Wayne]], [[Lil' Kim]], [[Raekwon]], [[T.A. All Day
column19: T.A.]] and [[Swizz Beatz]] and R&B singers [[Akon]], [[Pleasure P]] and [[T-Pain]].

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: The album garnered a mixed reception from critics who felt it borrowed too much from current hip-hop trends to regain both commercial success and relevancy for Joe. ''Jealous Ones Still Envy 2'' debuted at number 73 on the [[Billboard 200

On February 26, 2009, Virgin Records announced that this album would be released on April 7.<ref name=\"press release\"/> It was later delayed to May 19, late June, and September 22,<ref name=\"XXL July\">{{cite magazine
column5: title=Fat Joe Sets September Release Date For J.O.S.E. 2
column10: accessdate=January 21, 2016}}</ref> before Joe announced on his [[Twitter]] feed that the album would be released on October 6.<ref>{{cite tweet
column14: title=FAT JOE on Twitter: \"OCT 6th (J.O.S.E 2)IN STORES!!!!!!! Make a NOTE OF IT!!!! CRACK!!!\"
column20: title=FAT JOE on Twitter: \"What's up everyone just got off a conf. Call with Label and we set the album date in stone 2day OCT 6th sorry for the wait!!!!! Jose2\"
column22: accessdate=July 30, 2009}}</ref> Fat Joe explained to ''XXL'' on May 22 that he delayed the album due to a lack of promotion.<ref name=\"XXL May\">{{cite magazine
column26: title=Fat Joe Blames Album Pushback On Lack Of Promotion
column30: accessdate=January 21, 2016}}</ref> The day of the label's announcement, Fat Joe held a listening party for the album.<ref>{{cite web
column33: title=Fat Joe Throws J.O.S.E 2 Listening Party
column36: accessdate=March 3, 2009}}</ref> Prior to the release of the album on October 6, rival [[50 Cent]], issued a number of viral videos poking fun at the album as it was about to be released. Fat Joe replied with messages via his Twitter page, saying; \"50 is sick that my album is so hot. That real music! Not that wack stuff him and his clowns are making.\"<ref>{{cite web

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: The first single was \"[[One (Fat Joe song)
Mora: One]]\" featuring [[Akon]]; Fat Joe commented that his marriage inspired this song.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Fat Joe Inspired By His Wife On 'One,' Featuring Akon
column9: accessdate=March 26, 2009}}</ref> \"One\" peaked at number 74 on the ''Billboard'' R&B chart. The second single is \"[[Aloha (Fat Joe song)
column10: Aloha]]\" featuring [[Pleasure P]] and [[Rico Love]].<ref>{{cite tweet
column14: title=Twitter / FAT JOE: @YaGirlTia I just did 2day

column8: title=Jealous One's Still Envy (J.O.S.E. 2) - Fat Joe

column6: title=Fat Joe :: Jealous Ones Still Envy (J.O.S.E. 2) :: Terror Squad/EMI Music

column8: title=Fat Joe: Jealous Ones Still Envy (J.O.S.E. 2)

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: ''Jealous Ones Still Envy 2'' received mixed reviews from [[Music journalism
Mora: music critics]] who found Joe trying too hard to recapture ''[[Jealous Ones Still Envy (J.O.S.E.)
Diaz}}: J.O.S.E.]]''{{'}}s commercial success while appealing to a younger hip-hop audience. Mariel Concepcion of ''[[Billboard (magazine)
column4: Billboard]]'' praised the production for being energetic and versatile for Joe to rap over, saying that \"the Bronx-bred rapper again proves that he's got a knack for infectious beats.\"<ref name=\"Billboard\"/> Sean A. Malcolm of ''[[XXL (magazine)
column5: XXL]]'' said that despite some tracks feeling dull and monotonous, he praised Joe for maintaining his New York roots while mixing it with his newfound Miami influence through his performance, concluding that \"Sequels rarely live up to the original, and ''J.O.S.E. 2'' is no exception. But, in the end, with his string of hits, Fat Joe still remains one to envy.\"<ref name=\"XXL\"/> [[AllMusic]]'s David Jeffries said that the album follows the same formula as ''J.O.S.E.'', noticing the tracks' high-end production and star-worthy featured artists saying, \"The track list is right-sized and the rhymes are amusing the whole way through, making the title the only thing left to gripe about.\"<ref name=\"AM\"/>

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: Steve 'Flash' Juon of ''RapReviews'' was mixed towards the album, noting that Joe goes back and forth delivering sub-standard lyrics over production that's commercially tasteful, saying that, \"I suppose Joe can't be blamed for trying to stay trendy so he doesn't become irrelevant, but in working hard to combat his complacency he's gone the opposite direction and become the one thing no rapper should ever be - the old dude in the room everybody's snickering at because he thinks he's being cool when he's not.\"<ref name=\"RR\"/> Andres Tardio of ''[[HipHopDX]]'' said that despite tracks like \"Congratulations\", \"One\" and \"Joey Don't Do It\" having eclectic production and sharp lyricism, the album falters with an overabundance of [[Auto-Tune]] over anonymous club tracks, saying that, \"Though ''J.O.S.E. 2'' shines when Joe is not chasing formulaic records, the cookie cutter style he often uses makes this album lose its impact.\"<ref name=\"HHDX\"/>
''Jealous Ones Still Envy 2'' debuted at number 73 on the [[Billboard 200
Mora: ''Billboard'' 200]] for the week of October 24, 2009<ref>{{cite magazine
column8: accessdate=January 22, 2016}}</ref> and only sold 8,300 copies for its first week<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=The Charts: Fat Joe Fails To Make Impact With ''J.O.S.E. 2''
column14: accessdate=January 22, 2016}}</ref> before leaving the chart the next week. By June 2010, the album had sold 20,000 copies in the United States.<ref>{{cite magazine
column18: title=Fat Joe Comes Back Swinging On 'The Dark Side'
column23: Vibe]]'' added the album in its list of twelve rap album sequels that should have never happened. ''Vibe'' editor Chris Yuscavage found it inferior to Joe's 2001 commercial breakthrough saying, \"With ''J.O.S.E. 2'', he tried to emulate that feeling by selecting a host of commercially-viable producers (Jim Jonsin, Rico Love and–''gulp''–Ron Browz, included) and failed ''miserably'' by deviating away from his core fan base. ''J.O.S.E. 2'' was too much of a bad thing.\"<ref>{{cite magazine

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: '''''Jealous Ones Still Envy 2 (J.O.S.E. 2)''''' is the ninth solo [[studio album]] by American rapper [[Fat Joe]], and is a sequel to his platinum-selling album ''[[Jealous Ones Still Envy (J.O.S.E.)
Mora: Jealous Ones Still Envy]]'' (2001).<ref name=\"DX\">{{cite magazine
column5: title=Fat Joe Set to Release J.O.S.E. 2
column14: title=Fat Joe Readies New Album: Jealous Ones Still Envy 2 Out April 7
column17: date=February 26, 2009}}</ref> It is also the third album in his [[Jealous One's Envy]] series. After several delays, the album was released on October 6, 2009. The album's production was done by [[Rico Love]], [[Ron Browz]], [[Lee Major
column18: The Inkredibles]], [[Eric Hudson]], [[Jim Jonsin]] and [[DJ Infamous]], and features guest contributions from rappers [[Lil Wayne]], [[Lil' Kim]], [[Raekwon]], [[T.A. All Day
column19: T.A.]] and [[Swizz Beatz]] and R&B singers [[Akon]], [[Pleasure P]] and [[T-Pain]].

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: The album garnered a mixed reception from critics who felt it borrowed too much from current hip-hop trends to regain both commercial success and relevancy for Joe. ''Jealous Ones Still Envy 2'' debuted at number 73 on the [[Billboard 200

On February 26, 2009, Virgin Records announced that this album would be released on April 7.<ref name=\"press release\"/> It was later delayed to May 19, late June, and September 22,<ref name=\"XXL July\">{{cite magazine
column5: title=Fat Joe Sets September Release Date For J.O.S.E. 2
column10: accessdate=January 21, 2016}}</ref> before Joe announced on his [[Twitter]] feed that the album would be released on October 6.<ref>{{cite tweet
column14: title=FAT JOE on Twitter: \"OCT 6th (J.O.S.E 2)IN STORES!!!!!!! Make a NOTE OF IT!!!! CRACK!!!\"
column20: title=FAT JOE on Twitter: \"What's up everyone just got off a conf. Call with Label and we set the album date in stone 2day OCT 6th sorry for the wait!!!!! Jose2\"
column22: accessdate=July 30, 2009}}</ref> Fat Joe explained to ''XXL'' on May 22 that he delayed the album due to a lack of promotion.<ref name=\"XXL May\">{{cite magazine
column26: title=Fat Joe Blames Album Pushback On Lack Of Promotion
column30: accessdate=January 21, 2016}}</ref> The day of the label's announcement, Fat Joe held a listening party for the album.<ref>{{cite web
column33: title=Fat Joe Throws J.O.S.E 2 Listening Party
column36: accessdate=March 3, 2009}}</ref> Prior to the release of the album on October 6, rival [[50 Cent]], issued a number of viral videos poking fun at the album as it was about to be released. Fat Joe replied with messages via his Twitter page, saying; \"50 is sick that my album is so hot. That real music! Not that wack stuff him and his clowns are making.\"<ref>{{cite web

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: The first single was \"[[One (Fat Joe song)
Mora: One]]\" featuring [[Akon]]; Fat Joe commented that his marriage inspired this song.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Fat Joe Inspired By His Wife On 'One,' Featuring Akon
column9: accessdate=March 26, 2009}}</ref> \"One\" peaked at number 74 on the ''Billboard'' R&B chart. The second single is \"[[Aloha (Fat Joe song)
column10: Aloha]]\" featuring [[Pleasure P]] and [[Rico Love]].<ref>{{cite tweet
column14: title=Twitter / FAT JOE: @YaGirlTia I just did 2day

column8: title=Jealous One's Still Envy (J.O.S.E. 2) - Fat Joe

column6: title=Fat Joe :: Jealous Ones Still Envy (J.O.S.E. 2) :: Terror Squad/EMI Music

column8: title=Fat Joe: Jealous Ones Still Envy (J.O.S.E. 2)

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: ''Jealous Ones Still Envy 2'' received mixed reviews from [[Music journalism
Mora: music critics]] who found Joe trying too hard to recapture ''[[Jealous Ones Still Envy (J.O.S.E.)
Diaz}}: J.O.S.E.]]''{{'}}s commercial success while appealing to a younger hip-hop audience. Mariel Concepcion of ''[[Billboard (magazine)
column4: Billboard]]'' praised the production for being energetic and versatile for Joe to rap over, saying that \"the Bronx-bred rapper again proves that he's got a knack for infectious beats.\"<ref name=\"Billboard\"/> Sean A. Malcolm of ''[[XXL (magazine)
column5: XXL]]'' said that despite some tracks feeling dull and monotonous, he praised Joe for maintaining his New York roots while mixing it with his newfound Miami influence through his performance, concluding that \"Sequels rarely live up to the original, and ''J.O.S.E. 2'' is no exception. But, in the end, with his string of hits, Fat Joe still remains one to envy.\"<ref name=\"XXL\"/> [[AllMusic]]'s David Jeffries said that the album follows the same formula as ''J.O.S.E.'', noticing the tracks' high-end production and star-worthy featured artists saying, \"The track list is right-sized and the rhymes are amusing the whole way through, making the title the only thing left to gripe about.\"<ref name=\"AM\"/>

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: Steve 'Flash' Juon of ''RapReviews'' was mixed towards the album, noting that Joe goes back and forth delivering sub-standard lyrics over production that's commercially tasteful, saying that, \"I suppose Joe can't be blamed for trying to stay trendy so he doesn't become irrelevant, but in working hard to combat his complacency he's gone the opposite direction and become the one thing no rapper should ever be - the old dude in the room everybody's snickering at because he thinks he's being cool when he's not.\"<ref name=\"RR\"/> Andres Tardio of ''[[HipHopDX]]'' said that despite tracks like \"Congratulations\", \"One\" and \"Joey Don't Do It\" having eclectic production and sharp lyricism, the album falters with an overabundance of [[Auto-Tune]] over anonymous club tracks, saying that, \"Though ''J.O.S.E. 2'' shines when Joe is not chasing formulaic records, the cookie cutter style he often uses makes this album lose its impact.\"<ref name=\"HHDX\"/>
''Jealous Ones Still Envy 2'' debuted at number 73 on the [[Billboard 200
Mora: ''Billboard'' 200]] for the week of October 24, 2009<ref>{{cite magazine
column8: accessdate=January 22, 2016}}</ref> and only sold 8,300 copies for its first week<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=The Charts: Fat Joe Fails To Make Impact With ''J.O.S.E. 2''
column14: accessdate=January 22, 2016}}</ref> before leaving the chart the next week. By June 2010, the album had sold 20,000 copies in the United States.<ref>{{cite magazine
column18: title=Fat Joe Comes Back Swinging On 'The Dark Side'
column23: Vibe]]'' added the album in its list of twelve rap album sequels that should have never happened. ''Vibe'' editor Chris Yuscavage found it inferior to Joe's 2001 commercial breakthrough saying, \"With ''J.O.S.E. 2'', he tried to emulate that feeling by selecting a host of commercially-viable producers (Jim Jonsin, Rico Love and–''gulp''–Ron Browz, included) and failed ''miserably'' by deviating away from his core fan base. ''J.O.S.E. 2'' was too much of a bad thing.\"<ref>{{cite magazine
column27: title=Jealous Ones Still Envy 2 (J.O.S.E. 2) - Not Again! 12 Rap Album Sequels That Should Have Never Happened

Mora: railroad station]] and transportation hub along the [[Main Line (Long Island Rail Road)
Diaz}}: Main Line]] of the [[Long Island Rail Road]] in [[Ronkonkoma, New York]]. The station is the eastern [[terminal station
column4: terminus]] of the [[Ronkonkoma Branch]] and the western terminus of the [[Greenport Branch]].

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: The station is located on Lakeland Street or Railroad Avenue North across from the intersection of Hawkins Avenue, and has parking facilities and other amenities that extend beyond the central location. Free parking is available in the lots adjacent to the tracks on the north and south side. One [[parking garage]] north of the station was built in 1996 on a former freight spur.<ref>[http://www.trainsarefun.com/lirr/Ronkonkoma/MP48-49%20ronk.jpg Ronkonkoma Milepost 48-49; Emery map - October 1957]</ref><ref>[http://www.trainsarefun.com/lirr/Ronkonkoma/ronkwyenorth78.jpg View Wye North (1978 Photo by Steve Lynch)]</ref> The station has a total of about 6,100 parking spaces.<ref>{{cite press release
column4: title=Ronkonkoma Parking Lot Renovation Completed; Almost 300 New Spots Now Available
column6: accessdate=March 9, 2010}}</ref> As of May 2011, 63 trains connecting to [[New York City]] stop at this station every weekday, while an additional nine make connections with stations to the east.<ref>{{cite web

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: Ronkonkoma Station was originally built as '''Lake Ronkonkoma''' station in 1883 as a replacement for the 1843-built '''Lakeland''' station designed to serve both [[Lakeland, Suffolk County, New York
Mora: Lakeland]] and [[Ronkonkoma, New York]], as well as the 1853-built '''Hermanville''' station, designed for a former community along the south side of the tracks.<ref>{{cite web

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: '''Lakeland''' was originally built in 1843 as '''Lake Road''' station. It was named for and located on Lake Road (now Pond Road), a street that once ran from [[Oakdale, New York
Mora: Oakdale]] to the east side of [[Lake Ronkonkoma (lake)
Diaz}}: Lake Ronkonkoma]] itself. By 1850 it was moved to the Dr. E. F. Peck General Store on the northwest corner of what is today Ocean Avenue and Lakeland Street. A freight house existed along the tracks close to Pine Avenue. Edgar Fenn Peck owned land as far south as [[Sayville, New York
column4: Sayville]], and in 1851 sold the store and the land to a developer named Charles Wood, who turned his land into a development named Lakeland Farms, which today includes land in Oakdale, [[Bohemia, New York
column5: Bohemia]], and what is now [[Ronkonkoma, New York
column6: Ronkonkoma]].<ref>[http://arrts-arrchives.com/hermannville.html Lake Road station, Hermanville station, Lake station, Lakeland station, Lakeland Farms, and Wood Lawn, Long Island  (Arrt's Arrchive)]</ref> The original Lake Road station operated simultaneously with the one at the general store on Ocean Avenue, and at some point was renamed \"Lake station,\" until eventually being phased out. No record of the original station's existence can be found after 1857.

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: '''Hermanville''' or '''Hermannville''' was another station stop along the [[Greenport Branch]] of the [[Long Island Rail Road]], located east of the former Lake Road Station. It first appeared on an 1850 map of the Long Island Rail Road.<ref>[http://arrts-arrchives.com/images3/HERMANNVILLEmapLIeast.jpg Hermannville Map]</ref> The station had one side platform, and two tracks. An 1852 advertisement for Hermanville in a few books mention the Long Island Rail Road.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=_G_pJck2iTsC&pg=PA252&lpg=PA252&dq=hermanville+long+island+railroad+station&source=bl&ots=ipLDdvLiGQ&sig=aXT8Ie0VDj5nSApETMkoIIyq4nY&hl=en&sa=X&ei=s_shVdb9KMu8ggSx1ICQDw&sqi=2&ved=0CFsQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=hermanville%20long%20island%20railroad%20station&f=false The Cultivator by Luther Tucker Advertisement for Hermannvile mentioning Long Island Railroad]</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=21tKAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA247&lpg=PA247&dq=hermanville+long+island+railroad+station&source=bl&ots=KQPT8t6mvQ&sig=ZFGUkxO7sjXJnzZpmMZPaUNBSX4&hl=en&sa=X&ei=lPwhVYexOMPLsAWahoG4Aw&ved=0CB0Q6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=hermanville%20long%20island%20railroad%20station&f=false The Genesee Farmer advertisement for Hermanville]</ref> Hermannville also made an appearance on the 1855 Colton map.<ref>[http://arrts-arrchives.com/images2/1855coltonCENTRE.jpg 1855 Hermannville Map]</ref> On the Map of The Village of Hermannville, Town of Islip, Suffolk County, Long Island, Hemannville station<ref>[http://arrts-arrchives.com/images3/HERMANNVILLEtraineb.jpg Hermanville Station]</ref> is shown as being at the intersection of the Main Line and Herman Avenue,<ref>[http://arrts-arrchives.com/images3/HERMANNVILLEmapWrr.jpg Hermannville Map]</ref><ref>[http://arrts-arrchives.com/images3/HERMANNVILLEdescr.jpg Hermannville description]</ref> which today is part of the Ronkonkoma Yard.
'''Lake Ronkonkoma''' station replaced Lakeland station in 1883 and was designed to serve both [[Lakeland, Suffolk County, New York
Mora: Lakeland]] and [[Ronkonkoma, New York]]. At some point, the word \"Lake\" was dropped from the station name. The station house was burned in 1934 and a temporary rectangular one-story building with a gabled roof was used until September 1937, when the second Ronkonkoma station was completed. Throughout much of the 20th Century, it also served as a sizeable freight hub for Central Suffolk County.

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: Since December 28, 1987, it has been the east end of the Main Line electrification<ref>{{cite web
column4: work=trainsarefun.com}}</ref> but stations east of Ronkonkoma have been modified for future electrification. The 1937 station was used for storage until it was razed in 1994 when part of the parking lot was extended westward. The current station was designed by architect Richard Henry Behr.<ref>{{cite web
column7: work=rhbpc.com}}</ref> Ronkonkoma Yard is also located east of the station, in close proximity to the former [[Holbrook (LIRR station)
column8: Holbrook]] station, which was torn down in 1962,<ref>[http://www.trainsarefun.com/lirr/Ronkonkoma/MP49-50%20ronk.jpg Ronkonkoma/Holbrook Milepost 49-50; Emery map (TrainsAreFun.com)]</ref> and has taken in commuters from the former [[Holtsville (LIRR station)

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: This station is set up using the [[Spanish solution]] with three high-level platforms, each 12 cars long. Platform B, an [[island platform]], facilitates a [[cross-platform interchange]] when a Ronkonkoma Branch train and a Greenport train arrive at the same time (a move also known as \"The Greenport Scoot\").<ref>{{cite web
Diaz}}: title=e-Train - TCA, Toy Trains, Train Collectors Association

Mora: style=\"border-top:solid 1px gray;border-bottom:solid 1px gray;\" width=100 rowspan=7 valign=top

column4: Platform A]], doors will open on the left or right from Track 1</small> {{access icon}}

Mora: style=\"border: 2px solid black; border-image: none; text-align: center;\" colspan=\"2\"
column4: Platform B]], doors will open on the left or right from either track</small> {{access icon}}

Mora: style=\"border-top:solid 2px black;border-right:solid 2px black;border-left:solid 2px black;border-bottom:solid 1px gray;text-align:center;\" colspan=2
column4: Platform C]], doors will open on the left or right from Track 2</small> {{access icon}}

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: East of the Ronkonkoma station is a 12-track train-storage yard called the Ronkonkoma Yard. As this is the eastern end of the electrified portion of the Main Line, the yard stores the [[electric multiple unit]]s that are used on the Ronkonkoma Branch.<ref name=MTA-MidSuffolk/>
In preparation for the LIRR's [[East Side Access]] expansion to [[Grand Central Terminal]], the MTA is adding 11 new tracks to the yard, for a total of 23 tracks.<ref name=MTA-MidSuffolk>{{cite web
column4: work=mta.info}}</ref> The expansion will use space already owned by the MTA located immediately to the south of the existing rail yard and north of [[Long Island MacArthur Airport
column5: MacArthur Airport]]. The increase in storage space will allow the MTA to increase peak-hour service to Manhattan. The project is budgeted for $128.0 million.<ref name=\"Jan 2013\">{{cite web
column15: title=MTA Long Island Rail Road Committee Meeting
column31: accessdate=November 2, 2015}}</ref> Locations in Deer Park, Central Islip, and Yaphank were also considered for the construction of the yard. The Deer Park option was dismissed as it would have impacted several grade crossings, duplicated employee facilities and as it would not have benefited riders east of the station. The Central Islip site was dismissed as it would have been located in [[Connetquot River State Park Preserve
column32: Connetquot River State Park]]. The Yaphank option was rejected because of the high cost of electrification and the requirement that stations between Ronkonkoma and Yaphank receive upgrades.<ref>{{cite web

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: Construction was expected to be finished by late 2018.<ref name=\"schedule\" /> However, {{As of
column4: alt=as of June 2017}} construction was to start in September 2017, with completion being pushed back to March 2020.<ref>{{Cite web
column6: title=L60601YN New Mid Suffolk Electric Yard
column12: access-date=September 3, 2017}}</ref> A construction award was finally made in December 2017, and the completion date was pushed back to late 2020.<ref name=\"MTA-CPOC-May2019\">{{Cite web

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: East of the Ronkonkoma station is a 12-track train-storage yard called the Ronkonkoma Yard. As this is the eastern end of the electrified portion of the Main Line, the yard stores the [[electric multiple unit]]s that are used on the Ronkonkoma Branch.<ref name=MTA-MidSuffolk/>
In preparation for the LIRR's [[East Side Access]] expansion to [[Grand Central Terminal]], the MTA is adding 11 new tracks to the yard, for a total of 23 tracks.<ref name=MTA-MidSuffolk>{{cite web
column4: work=mta.info}}</ref> The expansion will use space already owned by the MTA located immediately to the south of the existing rail yard and north of [[Long Island MacArthur Airport
column5: MacArthur Airport]]. The increase in storage space will allow the MTA to increase peak-hour service to Manhattan. The project is budgeted for $128.0 million.<ref name=\"Jan 2013\">{{cite web
column15: title=MTA Long Island Rail Road Committee Meeting
column31: accessdate=November 2, 2015}}</ref> Locations in Deer Park, Central Islip, and Yaphank were also considered for the construction of the yard. The Deer Park option was dismissed as it would have impacted several grade crossings, duplicated employee facilities and as it would not have benefited riders east of the station. The Central Islip site was dismissed as it would have been located in [[Connetquot River State Park Preserve
column32: Connetquot River State Park]]. The Yaphank option was rejected because of the high cost of electrification and the requirement that stations between Ronkonkoma and Yaphank receive upgrades.<ref>{{cite web

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: Construction was expected to be finished by late 2018.<ref name=\"schedule\" /> However, {{As of
column4: alt=as of June 2017}} construction was to start in September 2017, with completion being pushed back to March 2020.<ref>{{Cite web
column6: title=L60601YN New Mid Suffolk Electric Yard
column12: access-date=September 3, 2017}}</ref> A construction award was finally made in December 2017, and the completion date was pushed back to late 2020.<ref name=\"MTA-CPOC-May2019\">{{Cite web

→‎Ethnic Kazakhs among the migrants:fixed some grammar, improved flow.,safe,The Mattador,"{{Infobox ethnic group
The number of '''Chinese people in Kazakhstan''' varies through the centuries. There have been various migrations of [[Ethnic minorities of China
Mora: ethnic minorities from China]] to Kazakhstan in the 19th and early 20th centuries, such as that of the [[Dungan people]] (Hui) fleeing [[Qing Dynasty]] forces after [[Dungan revolt (1862–1877)
Diaz}}: a failed 1862–1877 rebellion]] in [[northwest China]], or the Uyghur and [[Kazakh exodus from Xinjiang]] during the 1950s [[Great Leap Forward]]; however, their descendants do not consider themselves to be \"[[Chinese people]]\".<ref>{{harvnb
column10: p=39}}</ref> The modern wave of migration from China only dates back to the early 1990s.<ref name=\"Sadovskaya2007a\">{{harvnb

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: As a result of centuries-old migrations from China, distinct ethnic diasporas emerged in Kazakhstan: Uyghurs – 246.449 people (2010),   Dungans (Hui) – 51.577 people (2010),  and Han Chinese – 3.424 people (2009). <ref name=\"Sadovskaya2017a\">{{harvnb
column4: p=162-170}}</ref> The Han Chinese is a highly urbanized ethnic group: 80% live in the cities, predominantly in Almaty, Nur-Sultan (former Astana) and Karaganda, and is well educated: 48.2% of Han have higher (university) and vocational education. <ref name=\"Sadovskaya2017b\">{{harvnb

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: During the [[Mongol Empire]], Han Chinese were moved to Central Asian areas like Besh Baliq, Almaliq, and Samarqand by the Mongols where they worked as artisans and farmers.<ref name=\"Biran2005\">{{cite book
Diaz}}: title=The Empire of the Qara Khitai in Eurasian History: Between China and the Islamic World
column8: pages=96–}}</ref> The Daoist Chinese master [[Qiu Chuji]] travelled through Kazakhstan to meet Genghis Khan in Afghanistan.

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: China and Kazakhstan agreed on visa-free travel in early 1992, which led to 150 to 200 Chinese citizens entering Kazakhstan each day and not returning to China. Most are believed to have simply used Kazakhstan as a transit point to Europe. Visa-free travel was terminated in 1993.<ref>{{harvnb
column4: p=151}}</ref> The border between the two countries remained strictly controlled and highly militarised until the 1995 China–Kazakhstan Joint Declaration, following which [[People's Liberation Army]] units in the region were redeployed to the borders with Tajikistan and Afghanistan in southern Xinjiang.<ref>{{harvnb
column7: pp=58–59}}</ref> Starting from them, many Chinese traders began flowing into Kazakhstan.<ref name=\"Parham2004\">{{harvnb
column10: p=61}}</ref> When the Kazakhstani government first opened a consulate in Ürümqi in 1997, it did not even issue visas to local people, but by 2004 it was possible for Chinese people to obtain business visas with an invitation from an organisation in Kazakhstan.<ref>{{harvnb

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: Some Kazakhstan popular media reports claimed there were as many as 300,000 Chinese people in Kazakhstan by the year 2000.<ref name=\"Parham2004\" /> An article from China's official [[Xinhua News Agency]] repeated this same number in 2009.<ref name=\"Xinhua\">{{citation
column6: title=新疆《哈萨克斯坦华侨报》通过哈方注册 4月底创刊/Xinjiang 'Kazakhstan Overseas Chinese Newspaper' Passes Kazakhstan Registration; To Begin Publishing at Month's end
column10: url-status=dead}}</ref> However, official entrance statistics by the National Security Committee of Kazakhstan showed only 46.0 thou in 2000, 91.5 thou in 2005, 134.9 thou in 2010 and 239.6 thou visitors from China in Kazakhstan in 2014 <ref name=\"Sadovskaya2016g\">{{harvnb
column13: p=40}}</ref>. Among visitors are citizens of various ethnicities: Han, Kazakhs, Uighurs, Dungans (Hui), Uzbeks, Koreans and others. They arrive with various purposes: official and business visits, private, tourism, labour, transit <ref name=\"Sadovskaya2016a\">{{harvnb

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: The recruitment of the working force from China, largely entering the country as employees of Chinese companies, dates back to 1993. 559 workers from China entered the country according to governmentally approved quota for attracting the foreign labour force. This grew to 1,457 by 2004, 5,008 by 2006 and 10,104 by 2010, making up 22% of the total foreign labour. <ref name=\"Sadovskaya2016c\">{{harvnb
column4: p=44-45}}</ref>. Initially, most were concentrated in Almaty, but more are spreading out to southern and western Kazakhstan as well. They are commonly employed in energy and construction companies.<ref name=\"Sadovskaya2007\" /> Some Chinese who have officially entered the country on short-term business visas for the purpose of trade are also in reality employed as labourers by Chinese companies.<ref name=\"Sadovskaya2007b\">{{harvnb

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: In the 2000s, independent entrepreneurs running import-export businesses, as well as larger investors, began to become more active.<ref>{{harvnb
column4: p=155}}</ref> Most of the products which Chinese traders sell are purchased in the special economic zones in the Xinjiang border regions.<ref>{{harvnb
column7: p=90}}</ref> Over 4,000 Chinese firms or Kazakhstani firms with some Chinese investors are officially registered with the government; however, {{asof

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: There is a Chinese bazaar in Almaty, the Barakholka Bazaar, which in addition to selling general Chinese-made products such as electronics or foodstuffs to local people, also sells products aimed at Chinese people such as Chinese pop music or Chinese-language newspapers. These are not in evidence in other urban areas.<ref>{{harvnb
column4: pp=79–80}}</ref> It came to be dominated by Uyghur and Dungan traders in the 1990s; it is actually located near the site of a former Dungan ''kolkhoz''<ref>{{harvnb
column8: p=98}}</ref> and the areas of traditional Uyghur settlement in Almaty - ''Zarya Vostoka'' village <ref name=\"Sadovskaya2016d\">{{harvnb

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: The Dungan have often played an intermediary role in business ventures between migrants from China and local people.<ref>{{harvnb

A Xinjiang-based [[free newspaper]] aimed at Chinese people in Kazakhstan, the ''Hāsàkèsītǎn Huáqiáo Bào'' (哈萨克斯坦华侨报, literally \"Kazakhstan Chinese Emigrant Newspaper\"), received permission from the Kazakhstan government in April 2009 to begin publication. The editors plan to publish it bilingually in both Russian and Chinese, with two issues of eight pages each per month. It is printed by the same department responsible for the ''[[Xinjiang Economic Daily]]''.<ref name=\"Xinhua\"/>

The Kazakh government has sought to promote permanent relocation of ethnic Kazakhs from abroad in Kazakhstan by providing them with financial assistance and land grants in border areas <ref name=\"Sadovskaya2016e\">{{harvnb
column4: p=52-56}}</ref>. However, this eventually requires them to give up their Chinese nationality and right of residence; according to Xinjiang media, many later come to regret this move <ref name=\"Parham2004a\">{{harvnb
column7: p=93}}</ref>. Kazakhs repariating from China have expressed that they experience difficulty integrating because they are more familiar with the Arabic orthography for the Kazakh language as used in China, rather than the [[Cyrillic script
column8: Cyrillic]] one used in Kazakhstan.  Further, they often speak only Chinese, and very rarely any Russian, as a second language<ref name=\"Sadovskaya2007a\" /><ref name=\"Parham2004b\">{{harvnb
column11: p=94}}</ref>. Kazakh repatriates from China tend to find jobs at Chinese companies or joint ventures.<ref name=\"Sadovskaya2007a\" />

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: According to the official data, in 1995-2014, Kazakhstan citizenship was granted in total to 73,800 individuals from China, of who 73,713 were Kazakh repatriates; 13 – Han Chinese, and 73 – other ethnicities (as of January 1, 2015)  <ref>{{harvnb
Since 1991 and until October 1, 2019, 1.057 mln ethnic Kazakh repatriates arrived to Kazakhstan. The number of oralmans from China was 13.2%, or around 139.6 thou people <ref>{{harvnb

Most are concentrated around Almaty and [[East Kazakhstan Province]].<ref name=\"Sadovskaya2007b\" /> They form the majority of teachers of the Chinese language at Kazakhstani universities.<ref>{{harvnb

Kazakhstanis generally express neutral attitudes towards Chinese migrants (55% of respondents in 2007). In 2012 this share with indifferent attitudes shrunk up to 44%, and the share of those with “poor” attitudes increased from 15 to 33%; respondents with positive attitudes accounted for 23% (26% in 2007) <ref>{{harvnb

There is even some opposition to the presence or further migration of Uyghurs or Kazakhs from Xinjiang, because of the perception that their presence may draw more Chinese influence into the country as well.<ref>{{harvnb
column4: p=81}}</ref> A 2009 proposal by the Chinese government to lease one million hectares of steppe for cultivation of [[soybean]]s sparked a series of protests in Almaty in December and January over the possibility that Chinese labourers would be brought to the country to work the land.<ref>{{citation
column10: title=Prospect of Chinese Farmers Brings Controversy to Kazakh Soil
column16: title=Kazakhs protest against China farmland lease

,unsafe,98.200.14.166,"{{Spanish name: According to the 2012 sociological survey, higher tolerance to Chinese migrants is observed among ethnic minorities and Russians, those aged 18-29 and 30-39, and respondents with higher educational levels <ref name=\"Sadovskaya2016f\">{{harvnb
column4: p=86}}</ref>. There is a popular perception that a large and rapidly growing number of Chinese people marry Kazakhstani citizens to obtain permanent residency in the country, but in fact, there were only 74 such marriages between 1991 and 2007.<ref>{{harvnb
publisher = Institut fur Ethnologie, Universitat Bern
